title: How to Make Bunny Tail Truffles

methods.name: Whipping Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cheesecake Truffles

steps.headline: Beat the cream cheese until it is fluffy.
steps.description: Add an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese that’s been softened to the bowl of a stand mixer. Insert the paddle attachment and beat the cream cheese on medium until it is light and fluffy, which should take approximately 30 seconds to 1 minute. You can soften the cream cheese by placing it in the microwave on a microwave-safe plate for 10 to 15 seconds. You can use a handheld electric mixer to mix the truffles if you prefer.

steps.headline: Mix in the powdered sugar a cup at a time.
steps.description: Once the cream cheese is fluffy, add 4 to 5 cups (440 to 550 g) of powdered sugar to the bowl. Beat the sugar in 1 cup (110 g) at a time, though, and mix well after each addition until a thick dough forms. Powdered sugar is also known as confectioners’ sugar or icing sugar. You’ll know the mixture has reached the right consistency if it holds its shape when you form it into a ball. If it is too loose, continue adding the sugar.

steps.headline: Roll the dough into balls.
steps.description: When the mixture has formed a thick dough, use clean hands to roll it into balls. Aim for balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large. You can adjust the size of the balls depending on how large you’d like the truffles to be.

steps.headline: Coat the balls with coconut and serve.
steps.description: After you’ve formed balls from the dough, fill a shallow dish with 2 to 3 cups (150 to 225 g) of sweetened coconut. Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them, pressing the flakes onto the dough to help them stick. Arrange the truffles on a platter and serve. If you’re having trouble getting the coconut to stick to the truffles, you can coat the dough lightly with corn syrup before rolling them in the flakes. Place any leftover truffles in an airtight container and store them in the refrigerator. They will keep for up to 4 days.

methods.name: Preparing Bunny Tail Coconut Cream Truffles

steps.headline: Chop the coconut.
steps.description: For the truffles, you’ll need 2 cups (150 g) of coconut. Use a sharp knife to finely chop the shreds and set aside for the moment. You can run the coconut through a food processor to finely chop it if you prefer.

steps.headline: Cook the sugar, cream, and butter until it reaches the right temperature.
steps.description: Add 6 cups (1.2 kg) of sugar, 1 ½ cups (355 ml) heavy cream, and ½ cup (113 g) of butter to a large pot with a candy thermometer attached. Heat the mixture over medium-high until it reaches 236 to 238 degrees Fahrenheit (113 to 114 degrees Celsius). Stir the mixture constantly with a whisk as you heat it. If you don’t have a candy thermometer, a deep fry thermometer will also work.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the heat and let it cool.
steps.description: When the mixture reaches the right temperature, take the pot off the heat. Allow the mixture to cool for 8 to 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture onto a cool, damp slab.
steps.description: Once the mixture has cooled, pour it out on a solid surface slab. The slab should be cool and slightly damp when you add the mixture to it. A quartz or granite countertop makes an ideal solid surface. If you don’t have the proper countertop, a quartz or granite slab cutting board will also work. Don’t scrape out all of the mixture. If there are bits that are stuck, leave them in the pot.

steps.headline: Scrape the mixture until it thickens.
steps.description: When the cream mixture is spread out on your slab, use a candy scraper or butter knife to work the mixture around the surface. Continue scraping it until it begins to thicken and is no longer glossy, which should take approximately 5 minutes. . Any straight edge tool should work for scraping the cream mixture. A clean wall scraper can even work.

steps.headline: Knead the vanilla, salt, and some of the coconut into the mixture.
steps.description: Once the cream mixture has thickened, add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of vanilla, a dash of salt, and 1 ¼ cups (94 g) of the finely chopped coconut to it. Use clean hands to knead the ingredients into the cream mixture until they are fully incorporated. If you prefer, you can use the candy scraper or butter knife to work the vanilla, salt, and coconut into the cream mixture.

steps.headline: Let the mixture sit in a plastic bag for several hours.
steps.description: When the truffle mixture is fully mixed, remove it from the slab and place it in a sealable plastic bag. Allow it to sit at room temperature for approximately 6 hours. If you like, you can prepare the truffle mixture the day before and allow it to sit out overnight.

steps.headline: Form balls with the mixture.
steps.description: After the truffle mixture has sat for about 6 hours, remove it from the bag. Roll it into balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large with clean hands.

steps.headline: Roll the balls in coconut and serve.
steps.description: Once you’ve finished making the balls, add the remaining ¾ cup (56 g) of finely chopped coconut to a shallow dish. Press the balls into the coconut to coat them thoroughly, and place on a dish to serve. Store any leftover truffles in a covered, airtight container at room temperature. They will last for up to a week.

methods.name: Mixing Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cookie Truffles

steps.headline: Combine the melted chocolate and cream cheese.
steps.description: Add 6 ounces (170 g) of melted white chocolate and an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese to the bowl of a stand mixer. Beat the mixture on medium speed until it is smooth. If you prefer, you can use a handheld electric mixer to make the truffles.

steps.headline: Mix in the cookies, rum, and salt.
steps.description: Once the chocolate and cream cheese are combined, add ¾ cup (80 g) of crushed coconut cookies, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of coconut rum, and ⅛ teaspoon (1 g) of kosher salt. Beat the mixture until it is just blended. Any type of plain coconut cookies will work for the recipe. You can substitute water for the rum if you prefer.

steps.headline: Spread the mixture in a lined pie plate and chill it.
steps.description: After the cookie mixture is blended, line a 9-inch (23-cm) pie plate with parchment paper. Use an offset spatula to spread the mixture over the plate, and cover with plastic wrap. Chill the mixture in the refrigerator for 2 hours.

steps.headline: Form balls with the mixture and chill them again overnight.
steps.description: When the mixture has chilled for a couple of hours, remove it from the fridge. Use clean hands to roll the cookie mixture into 1-inch (2.5-cm) balls, and place them in a parchment-lined pan. Return them to the refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours. Make sure to cover the pan with the truffles with a piece of plastic wrap before you chill them.

steps.headline: Roll the balls in coconut and chill just before serving.
steps.description: An hour before you plan to serve the truffles, add 1 ½ cups (112 g) of shredded coconut to a shallow dish. Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them and chill them for another hour. To serve, remove them from the refrigerator and place on a platter. Refrigerate any leftover truffles in a single layer in an airtight container. They should last for up to a week.

tyn: Bunny Tail White Chocolate Cheesecake Truffles
text: Whipping Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cheesecake Truffles Beat the cream cheese until it is fluffy. Add an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese that’s been softened to the bowl of a stand mixer. Insert the paddle attachment and beat the cream cheese on medium until it is light and fluffy, which should take approximately 30 seconds to 1 minute. You can soften the cream cheese by placing it in the microwave on a microwave-safe plate for 10 to 15 seconds. You can use a handheld electric mixer to mix the truffles if you prefer. Mix in the powdered sugar a cup at a time. Once the cream cheese is fluffy, add 4 to 5 cups (440 to 550 g) of powdered sugar to the bowl. Beat the sugar in 1 cup (110 g) at a time, though, and mix well after each addition until a thick dough forms. Powdered sugar is also known as confectioners’ sugar or icing sugar. You’ll know the mixture has reached the right consistency if it holds its shape when you form it into a ball. If it is too loose, continue adding the sugar. Roll the dough into balls. When the mixture has formed a thick dough, use clean hands to roll it into balls. Aim for balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large. You can adjust the size of the balls depending on how large you’d like the truffles to be. Coat the balls with coconut and serve. After you’ve formed balls from the dough, fill a shallow dish with 2 to 3 cups (150 to 225 g) of sweetened coconut. Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them, pressing the flakes onto the dough to help them stick. Arrange the truffles on a platter and serve. If you’re having trouble getting the coconut to stick to the truffles, you can coat the dough lightly with corn syrup before rolling them in the flakes. Place any leftover truffles in an airtight container and store them in the refrigerator. They will keep for up to 4 days. Preparing Bunny Tail Coconut Cream Truffles Chop the coconut. For the truffles, you’ll need 2 cups (150 g) of coconut. Use a sharp knife to finely chop the shreds and set aside for the moment. You can run the coconut through a food processor to finely chop it if you prefer. Cook the sugar, cream, and butter until it reaches the right temperature. Add 6 cups (1.2 kg) of sugar, 1 ½ cups (355 ml) heavy cream, and ½ cup (113 g) of butter to a large pot with a candy thermometer attached. Heat the mixture over medium-high until it reaches 236 to 238 degrees Fahrenheit (113 to 114 degrees Celsius). Stir the mixture constantly with a whisk as you heat it. If you don’t have a candy thermometer, a deep fry thermometer will also work. Remove the mixture from the heat and let it cool. When the mixture reaches the right temperature, take the pot off the heat. Allow the mixture to cool for 8 to 10 minutes. Pour the mixture onto a cool, damp slab. Once the mixture has cooled, pour it out on a solid surface slab. The slab should be cool and slightly damp when you add the mixture to it. A quartz or granite countertop makes an ideal solid surface. If you don’t have the proper countertop, a quartz or granite slab cutting board will also work. Don’t scrape out all of the mixture. If there are bits that are stuck, leave them in the pot. Scrape the mixture until it thickens. When the cream mixture is spread out on your slab, use a candy scraper or butter knife to work the mixture around the surface. Continue scraping it until it begins to thicken and is no longer glossy, which should take approximately 5 minutes. . Any straight edge tool should work for scraping the cream mixture. A clean wall scraper can even work. Knead the vanilla, salt, and some of the coconut into the mixture. Once the cream mixture has thickened, add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of vanilla, a dash of salt, and 1 ¼ cups (94 g) of the finely chopped coconut to it. Use clean hands to knead the ingredients into the cream mixture until they are fully incorporated. If you prefer, you can use the candy scraper or butter knife to work the vanilla, salt, and coconut into the cream mixture. Let the mixture sit in a plastic bag for several hours. When the truffle mixture is fully mixed, remove it from the slab and place it in a sealable plastic bag. Allow it to sit at room temperature for approximately 6 hours. If you like, you can prepare the truffle mixture the day before and allow it to sit out overnight. Form balls with the mixture. After the truffle mixture has sat for about 6 hours, remove it from the bag. Roll it into balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large with clean hands. Roll the balls in coconut and serve. Once you’ve finished making the balls, add the remaining ¾ cup (56 g) of finely chopped coconut to a shallow dish. Press the balls into the coconut to coat them thoroughly, and place on a dish to serve. Store any leftover truffles in a covered, airtight container at room temperature. They will last for up to a week. Mixing Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cookie Truffles Combine the melted chocolate and cream cheese. Add 6 ounces (170 g) of melted white chocolate and an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese to the bowl of a stand mixer. Beat the mixture on medium speed until it is smooth. If you prefer, you can use a handheld electric mixer to make the truffles. Mix in the cookies, rum, and salt. Once the chocolate and cream cheese are combined, add ¾ cup (80 g) of crushed coconut cookies, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of coconut rum, and ⅛ teaspoon (1 g) of kosher salt. Beat the mixture until it is just blended. Any type of plain coconut cookies will work for the recipe. You can substitute water for the rum if you prefer. Spread the mixture in a lined pie plate and chill it. After the cookie mixture is blended, line a 9-inch (23-cm) pie plate with parchment paper. Use an offset spatula to spread the mixture over the plate, and cover with plastic wrap. Chill the mixture in the refrigerator for 2 hours. Form balls with the mixture and chill them again overnight. When the mixture has chilled for a couple of hours, remove it from the fridge. Use clean hands to roll the cookie mixture into 1-inch (2.5-cm) balls, and place them in a parchment-lined pan. Return them to the refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours. Make sure to cover the pan with the truffles with a piece of plastic wrap before you chill them. Roll the balls in coconut and chill just before serving. An hour before you plan to serve the truffles, add 1 ½ cups (112 g) of shredded coconut to a shallow dish. Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them and chill them for another hour. To serve, remove them from the refrigerator and place on a platter. Refrigerate any leftover truffles in a single layer in an airtight container. They should last for up to a week.
sentences: Whipping Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cheesecake Truffles Beat the cream cheese until it is fluffy.
Add an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese that’s been softened to the bowl of a stand mixer.
Insert the paddle attachment and beat the cream cheese on medium until it is light and fluffy, which should take approximately 30 seconds to 1 minute.
You can soften the cream cheese by placing it in the microwave on a microwave-safe plate for 10 to 15 seconds.
You can use a handheld electric mixer to mix the truffles if you prefer.
Mix in the powdered sugar a cup at a time.
Once the cream cheese is fluffy, add 4 to 5 cups (440 to 550 g) of powdered sugar to the bowl.
Beat the sugar in 1 cup (110 g) at a time, though, and mix well after each addition until a thick dough forms.
Powdered sugar is also known as confectioners’ sugar or icing sugar.
You’ll know the mixture has reached the right consistency if it holds its shape when you form it into a ball.
If it is too loose, continue adding the sugar.
Roll the dough into balls.
When the mixture has formed a thick dough, use clean hands to roll it into balls.
Aim for balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large.
You can adjust the size of the balls depending on how large you’d like the truffles to be.
Coat the balls with coconut and serve.
After you’ve formed balls from the dough, fill a shallow dish with 2 to 3 cups (150 to 225 g) of sweetened coconut.
Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them, pressing the flakes onto the dough to help them stick.
Arrange the truffles on a platter and serve.
If you’re having trouble getting the coconut to stick to the truffles, you can coat the dough lightly with corn syrup before rolling them in the flakes.
Place any leftover truffles in an airtight container and store them in the refrigerator.
They will keep for up to 4 days.
Preparing Bunny Tail Coconut Cream Truffles Chop the coconut.
For the truffles, you’ll need 2 cups (150 g) of coconut.
Use a sharp knife to finely chop the shreds and set aside for the moment.
You can run the coconut through a food processor to finely chop it if you prefer.
Cook the sugar, cream, and butter until it reaches the right temperature.
Add 6 cups (1.2 kg) of sugar, 1 ½ cups (355 ml) heavy cream, and ½ cup (113 g) of butter to a large pot with a candy thermometer attached.
Heat the mixture over medium-high until it reaches 236 to 238 degrees Fahrenheit (113 to 114 degrees Celsius).
Stir the mixture constantly with a whisk as you heat it.
If you don’t have a candy thermometer, a deep fry thermometer will also work.
Remove the mixture from the heat and let it cool.
When the mixture reaches the right temperature, take the pot off the heat.
Allow the mixture to cool for 8 to 10 minutes.
Pour the mixture onto a cool, damp slab.
Once the mixture has cooled, pour it out on a solid surface slab.
The slab should be cool and slightly damp when you add the mixture to it.
A quartz or granite countertop makes an ideal solid surface.
If you don’t have the proper countertop, a quartz or granite slab cutting board will also work.
Don’t scrape out all of the mixture.
If there are bits that are stuck, leave them in the pot.
Scrape the mixture until it thickens.
When the cream mixture is spread out on your slab, use a candy scraper or butter knife to work the mixture around the surface.
Continue scraping it until it begins to thicken and is no longer glossy, which should take approximately 5 minutes.
Any straight edge tool should work for scraping the cream mixture.
A clean wall scraper can even work.
Knead the vanilla, salt, and some of the coconut into the mixture.
Once the cream mixture has thickened, add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of vanilla, a dash of salt, and 1 ¼ cups (94 g) of the finely chopped coconut to it.
Use clean hands to knead the ingredients into the cream mixture until they are fully incorporated.
If you prefer, you can use the candy scraper or butter knife to work the vanilla, salt, and coconut into the cream mixture.
Let the mixture sit in a plastic bag for several hours.
When the truffle mixture is fully mixed, remove it from the slab and place it in a sealable plastic bag.
Allow it to sit at room temperature for approximately 6 hours.
If you like, you can prepare the truffle mixture the day before and allow it to sit out overnight.
Form balls with the mixture.
After the truffle mixture has sat for about 6 hours, remove it from the bag.
Roll it into balls that are approximately 1-inch (2.5-cm) large with clean hands.
Roll the balls in coconut and serve.
Once you’ve finished making the balls, add the remaining ¾ cup (56 g) of finely chopped coconut to a shallow dish.
Press the balls into the coconut to coat them thoroughly, and place on a dish to serve.
Store any leftover truffles in a covered, airtight container at room temperature.
They will last for up to a week.
Mixing Up Bunny Tail Coconut Cookie Truffles Combine the melted chocolate and cream cheese.
Add 6 ounces (170 g) of melted white chocolate and an 8-ounce (225 g) package of cream cheese to the bowl of a stand mixer.
Beat the mixture on medium speed until it is smooth.
If you prefer, you can use a handheld electric mixer to make the truffles.
Mix in the cookies, rum, and salt.
Once the chocolate and cream cheese are combined, add ¾ cup (80 g) of crushed coconut cookies, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of coconut rum, and ⅛ teaspoon (1 g) of kosher salt.
Beat the mixture until it is just blended.
Any type of plain coconut cookies will work for the recipe.
You can substitute water for the rum if you prefer.
Spread the mixture in a lined pie plate and chill it.
After the cookie mixture is blended, line a 9-inch (23-cm) pie plate with parchment paper.
Use an offset spatula to spread the mixture over the plate, and cover with plastic wrap.
Chill the mixture in the refrigerator for 2 hours.
Form balls with the mixture and chill them again overnight.
When the mixture has chilled for a couple of hours, remove it from the fridge.
Use clean hands to roll the cookie mixture into 1-inch (2.5-cm) balls, and place them in a parchment-lined pan.
Return them to the refrigerator for 12 to 24 hours.
Make sure to cover the pan with the truffles with a piece of plastic wrap before you chill them.
Roll the balls in coconut and chill just before serving.
An hour before you plan to serve the truffles, add 1 ½ cups (112 g) of shredded coconut to a shallow dish.
Roll the balls through the coconut to coat them and chill them for another hour.
To serve, remove them from the refrigerator and place on a platter.
Refrigerate any leftover truffles in a single layer in an airtight container.
They should last for up to a week.
